sn52.8:4.1: At one time Venerable Anuruddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the frankincense-tree hut.
sn52.8:4.2: There Venerable Anuruddha addressed the mendicants:
sn52.8:4.4: “Reverends, suppose that, although the Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east,
sn52.8:4.5: a large crowd were to come along with a spade and basket, saying:
sn52.8:4.6: ‘We’ll make this Ganges river slant, slope, and incline to the west!’
sn52.8:4.7: What do you think, reverends? Would they succeed?”
sn52.8:4.10: The Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east.
sn52.8:4.11: It’s not easy to make it slant, slope, and incline to the west.
sn52.8:4.12: That large crowd will eventually get weary and frustrated.”
sn52.8:5.1: “In the same way, while a mendicant develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path, if rulers or their ministers, friends or colleagues, relatives or family should invite them to accept wealth, saying:
sn52.8:5.2: ‘Please, mister, why let these ocher robes torment you?
sn52.8:5.3: Why follow the practice of shaving your head and carrying an alms bowl?
sn52.8:5.4: Come, return to a lesser life, enjoy wealth, and make merit!’
sn52.8:6.1: It’s simply impossible for a mendicant who is developing and cultivating the four kinds of mindfulness meditation to abandon the training and return to a lesser life.
sn52.8:6.4: Because for a long time that mendicant’s mind has slanted, sloped, and inclined to seclusion. So it’s impossible for them to return to a lesser life.
sn52.8:6.6: And how does a mendicant develop and cultivate the four kinds of mindfulness meditation?
sn52.8:6.7: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body …
sn52.8:6.10: principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn52.8:6.11: That’s how a mendicant develops and cultivates the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.”
